question: Seo (cwen) #### ferþ to þæm beorgum⁠ — The queen goes to the mountains
explanation: Here 'cwen' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Wæs (giefu) #### Hroþgares oft geæhted⁠ — The gift of Hrothgar was often prized
explanation: Here 'giefu' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Seo (ceaster) #### ne mæg beon behyd⁠ — The city cannot be hidden
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Sceolde manig blachleor (ides) #### bifiende gan⁠ — Many a pale-faced lady must trembling go
explanation: Here 'ides' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Þa (cwen) #### wæron hatene Marsepia and Lampida⁠ — The queens were called Marsepia and Lampida
explanation: Here 'cwen' is the subject and plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Hie ælmihtiges (giefu) #### anforleten⁠ — They might lose the almighty's gifts
explanation: Here 'giefu' is plural and directly receiving the action of the verb 'forleten', so it loses its 'u' and takes an 'a' ending

question: Ða (ceaster) ####, Gleawanceaster, Cirenceaster and Baþanceaster, beoþ on ceastrum weallum beworhte⁠ — The cities, Gloucester, Cirencester and Bath, are walled towns
explanation: Here 'ceastra' is the subject and plural, so it loses its second 'e' takes an 'a' ending

question: Ða (ides) #### sloh ða wundenlocc þone feondsceaðan⁠ — The women slew the wavy-haired fiend
explanation: Here 'ides' is the subject and plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Heo ferde to þære (cwen) #### broce ond fram þære cwene broce⁠ — She went to the Queen's brook and from the Queen's brook
explanation: Here 'cwen' is in the posessive singular, so it takes an 'e' ending

question: Ðære (ceaster) #### ealdorman spræc mid þæm biscope⁠ — The city's elderman spoke with the bishop
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is in the posessive singular, so it loses its second 'e' and takes an 'e' ending

question: Ðæra oðer wæs (ides) #### onlicnes⁠ — The other had a woman's likeness
explanation: Here 'ides' is in the posessive singular, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: He wæs on ðara (cwen) #### gewealdum⁠ — He was under the power of the queens
explanation: Here 'cwen' is in the posessive plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Ðara (ceaster) #### wisra menn ferde to þæm cyning⁠ — The cities wise men went to the king
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is in the posessive plural, so it loses its second 'e' and takes an 'a' ending

question: Ðara (ides) #### fæder wæs sæt æt wine⁠ — The ladies father was sat at his wine
explanation: Here 'ides' is in the posessive plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Ic seah feaxhar (cwen) ####⁠ — I saw a hoary-haired woman
explanation: Here 'cwen' is the direct object and singular, so it takes an 'e' ending

question: Heo gefylled wæs wisdomes (giefu) ####⁠ — She was filled with wisdom's gift
explanation: Here 'giefu' is the direct object and singular, so it loses its 'u' and takes an 'e' ending

question: Ælla and Cissa ymbsæton þa (ceaster) ####⁠ — Aella and Cissa beseiged the city
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is the direct object and singular, so it loses its second 'e' and takes an 'e' ending

question: Weras and (ides) #### sceolan læran Godes lufan⁠ — Men and women shall learn God's love
explanation: Here 'ides' is the subject and plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Ða þegnas læston þa (cwen) ####⁠ — The thanes followed the Queens
explanation: Here 'cwen' is the direct object and plural, so it takes an 'a' ending

question: Se Hælend ymbfor ealle þa burga ond þa (ceaster) ####⁠ — Jesus went around all the villages and the cities
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is the direct object and plural, so it loses its second 'e' and takes an 'a' ending

question: To saulum on heofonum þu selest weorþlica (giefu) ####⁠ — To the souls in heaven you will give worthy gifts
explanation: Here 'giefu' is the direct object and plural, so it loses its 'u' and takes an 'a' ending

question: Ða comon ða weardas to þære (ceaster) ####⁠ — Then the keepers came into the city
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is an indirect object and singular, so it loses its second 'e' and takes an 'e' ending

question: Ða þegnas ferde to þære (ides) ####⁠ — The thanes went to the lady
explanation: Here 'ides' is an indirect object and singular, so it takes an 'e' ending

question: Hie to ðære (cwen) #### agefon him⁠ — Then they gave him up to the queen
explanation: Here 'cwen' is an indirect object and singular, so it takes an 'e' ending

question: He ferde to þæm ceastre mid þæs cyninges (giefu) ####⁠ — He went to the city with the king's gift
explanation: Here 'giefu' is an indirect object and singular, so it loses its 'u' and takes an 'e' ending

question: Hlynn wearþ on þæm (ceaster) ####⁠ — A great cry arose in the cities
explanation: Here 'ceaster' is an indirect object and plural, so it loses its second 'e' and takes a 'um' ending

question: He geaf þa bec to þæm (ides) ####⁠ — He gave the books to the ladies
explanation: Here 'ides' is an indirect object and plural, so it takes a 'um' ending

question: Ða þegnas geaf begas ond feoh to þæm (cwen) ####⁠ — The thanes gave rings and wealth to the queens
explanation: Here 'cwen' is an indirect object and plural, so it takes a 'um' ending

question: Ðin mod trymeþ mid godcundum (giefu) ####⁠ — Strengthen your mind with divine gifts
explanation: Here 'giefu' is an indirect object and plural, so it takes a 'um' ending
